narration_segments.text: A string is wrapped around a wheel of moment of inertia point two kilogram meter square and radius twenty centimeters.
The wheel is initially at rest and the string is pulled with a force of twenty newtons.
Let us calculate the angular velocity of the wheel after five seconds.
The applied force produces a torque on the wheel equal to force multiplied by radius.
Using the given values, the torque is four newton meter.
Angular acceleration is torque divided by moment of inertia.
The angular acceleration comes out to be twenty radians per second square.
Starting from rest, the angular velocity after five seconds is one hundred radians per second.
